before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"3v5kv","text":"Review the protocols and figures below to learn how the IMPLEN nano spectrophotometer, Qubit fluorometer, and TapeStation electrophoresis systems work. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cj21f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"3rd4p","text":"Overview and Goals","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4euj","text":"Your bacterial isolate has been grown on agar plates, lysed open and genomic DNA has been isolated for sequencing. Next, we need to quantify our DNA yield and assess its integrity. For this, we will use the IMPLEN nano spectrophotometer and Qubit to measure our DNA quantity. We will also use an Agilent TapeStation electrophoresis system to assess the size of the DNA and quality the different bands.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ddf3l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3bci6","text":"After completing this lab, you will gain the following lab skills:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5398","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dvkr","text":"Lab safety and proper personal protective equipment (PPE)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a3i60","text":"Proper use of an IMPLEN nano spectrophotometer and Qubit fluorometer to analyze DNA samples.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2i699","text":"DNA concentration and integrity analysis using absorbance, fluorescence, and gel electrophoresis.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"31ojd","text":"Follow the steps carefully and pay attention to your instructor's guidance. Ask questions when necessary. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Activity 1: Quantification of DNA with the IMPLEN Nano Spectrophotometer
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"enbhh","text":"Wipe off your sample from the sample window and top sensor with a Kimwipe. You may use distilled water sprayed on a Kimwipe and dried with another one to clean the pedestal and mirror.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aa7bt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d60aj","text":"This is crucial to ensuring accurate and consistent results. Two or three wipes on each side is fine, but be sure it is dry each time before moving onto the next sample. Only after cleaning the pedestal can you start to add another sample.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Activity 1: Quantification of DNA with the IMPLEN Nano Spectrophotometer
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"euknr","text":"Clean the sample window and top sensor by pipetting 2 Î¼L of water onto the sample window, lowering the arm, and gently tapping the arm to make sure that the water contacts the top sensor. {"blocks":[{"key":"7qjfn","text":"Calibration of the Qubitâ¢ Fluorometer requires the standards to be inserted into the instrument in the right order. Read the prompts from the Qubit to insert the standards in the correct order. Note: we will assist you through this process. The information provided below is so you can review the entire process. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"57e9g","text":"On the Home screen of the Qubitâ¢ Fluorometer, press the 1X dsDNA High Sensitivity (HS) assay icon. The âRead standardsâ screen is displayed. Press Read Standards \u0026 run samples to proceed. Note: If you have already performed a calibration for the selected assay, the instrument prompts you to choose between reading new standards and running samples using the previous calibration. If you want to use the previous calibration, press Run samples and skip to step 2.4. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"54ihi","text":"Insert the tube containing Standard #1 into the sample chamber, close the lid, then press Run standards. When the reading is complete (~3 seconds), remove Standard #1.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cojri","text":"Insert the tube containing Standard #2 into the sample chamber, close the lid, and then press Read standards. When the reading is complete, remove Standard #2. The instrument displays the graphical results on the Standards complete screen. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9dgt6","text":"Press Next from the Standards complete screen to read your Samples. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9soij","text":"In the Sample volume screen, enter the sample volume added to the assay tube (from 1-20 ÂµL). Enter the volume directly in the sample volume text box, use the + or â buttons or adjust the sample volume wheel to select the sample volume added to the assay tube. Note: The sample volume used (1-20 ÂµL) changes the assay accuracy range. A different sample volume or assay may be required if the sample concentration is outside of what the assay can accurately quantify. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9trq3","text":"Insert a sample tube into the sample chamber, close the lid, then press Run sample. When the reading is complete (~3 seconds), remove the sample tube. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"e4tqo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3shb4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"78lf6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"64s1h","text":"Critical Thinking Questions for Quantifying and Checking Genomic DNA","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"57pad","text":"Before you measure your DNA sample using the Nanodrop, you blank it using the solvent your DNA is dissolved in. ","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":1,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8brig","text":"What do you think the impact of using the wrong solvent could be? Ex: Using water instead of TE buffer.","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":1,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c6g1a","text":"What do you think would happen if you \"blanked\" the Nanodrop using your DNA sample? Would you be able to detect your DNA measurement?","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5n1ge","text":"The Nanodrop uses photospectrometry to measure your sample, while the Qubit uses fluorescence activity from chemicals that can bind DNA. What do you think are some advantages of using each method?","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6nj9r","text":"Compare your data from the Nanodrop and the Qubit: are they similar or different quantifications? If they are different, which would you trust and why?","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7egtm","text":"From the TapeStation we will receive a DNA integrity number (DIN). What does a higher (Ex: 9) or lower value (Ex:4) tell you about your DNA?","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"choth","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ae1lm","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Activity 1: Quantification of DNA with the IMPLEN Nano Spectrophotometer
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"errug","text":"Create an Excel or Google spreadsheet to keep track of your data from Implen. Title it with the date and the name of your samples. Record the following values:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"auu4n","text":"the concentration of your DNA in ng/Âµl, ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bgkk9","text":"the ratio of the absorbance at 260 and 280. DNA should have a ratio of 1.8; if RNA is present, the ratio will be higher. If protein is present, the ratio will be lower than 1.8.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5bvej","text":"230/260 ratio that is used to learn about other substances that may be in your sample. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
